2019 Teams.Project Detail: Team Lora designed and implemented modifications to a walker to make it more stable and robust over a variety of terrains
Team Alex designed and built a device to allow a father with limited upper mobility to play catch with his children
Team Reese created a customized, comfortable neck brace for a teenager; a stable neck brace can enable the wearer to use eye gaze technology
Team Ellen prototyped flipit, a device to allow a person in a wheelchair to independently move their foot plate up and down to allow them to get in and out of a wheelchair independently
Team Sarah created the bom bidet, an easy-to-use portable bidet to make public restrooms more usable for people with limited upper mobility
Team Charbel created an app to help read seven-segment displays for people with low vision
Team Phil designed a DIY economical stander, and put together easy instructions so others can easily follow their process
Team Susan prototype technology to make classroom text (e.g. blackboards and projections) more visually accessible for people with low vision
Team Haoran worked on image filtering for classroom magnification devices for people with low vision
Team Jan worked on prototypes for people with limited grip strength to hold coffee cups and highlighters
Team Kartik prototyped a technology that helps people with visual impairments connect directly with friends and family for navigational assistance
Team Colette created the design of an app to help people with diabetes select and track the glycemic content of meals
Team Rishi prototyped breathable, comfortable night splits that do not tangle with themselves or a comforter
Team Julian prototyped a platform for a young man who doesn’t like wheelchairs to rest his feed on when he is in a stander
Team Zary prototyped a lever to allow a person in a wheelchair to access bags put on the back of the chair
Team Konrad prototyped modifications to an electro-larynx to allow for seamless pitch control, to allow the wearer to better control their voice’s emotion and personality

2018 Teams.Project Detail: Worked on the design of a portable device to help Adrianna safely and comfortably shower while traveling

2018 Teams.Project Description: Improved Chair Performance for Power Soccer
2018 Teams.Project Detail: Modified Juan's wheelchair to play power soccer more competitively (within the rules of the league), like improved kicking performance via ultra capacitor energy storage and wireless communication between team members
Designed a mechanism to make closing zippers with one arm easier

Prototyped two wearable devices for blood pressure monitoring:
  1. modifying existing blood pressure monitoring devices to be easily used by someone with one arm
  2. a prototype device using novel sensing mechanisms described in published literature

Designed and fabricated a device that allowed Kate, who uses cochlear implants, to use earbuds.
Their work was documented here Airpod Wireless Earbuds, Wired Earbuds.
Designed and fabricated a prototype of a wearable arm band that vibrates to alert Annette, who is deaf, when her doorbell rings

2017 Teams.Project Detail: Alex graduated from Emerson College and is an award-winning filmmaker. He has cerebral palsy, which affects his ability to control his video camera and DSLR. He would like to be able to take film and photos independently. He would like a device to help him remotely move his camera around and control the camera settings while viewing the shot.

Dan was diagnosed with spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy at birth. He is very social and has a great sense of humor. If you let him, he will “talk” your ear off. Because of his cerebral palsy, he has muscle stiffness in his arms, leg, and torso and he communicates and controls his tablet via head movements. He would like to work on technology that could help him have some more independence/control – like turning on and off the TV, changing the channel, and/or a call light for when he needs to use the bathroom.

Evan is an occupational therapist at Toward Independent Living and Learning. One residents that he works with, Meri uses a head pointer to operate her iPad but finds commercially available head pointers clunky and ugly. She would like a sturdy, comfortable, attractive, reproducible head pointer.

2016 Teams.Project Detail: Colleen sometimes falls when getting out of her wheelchair and has difficulty getting back up. She needs to be seated in order to transfer to her walker and then back into her chair. The team designed a system that she could move herself to that provides a lift assist to get her up high enough to stand back up with the assistance of a walker. A scale embedded into the seat of the power lift chair also provides weight information which is also difficult to obtain without a special scale meant for a wheelchair. This information is sent to an online interface for easy visualization and tracking.

The team built a customized, foldable cane attachment for a visually impaired wheelchair user to help navigate without getting in the way of a guide dog. The cane can be folded into multiple configuations for easy storage on publication transporation, or going through a doorway with magnetlic links. There are two grip positions for the cane to maximize comfort.

The team worked with a teenager who does not communicate verbally. They made a storybook for her that she can show people to introduce herself, and a platform that allows her to touch other people on the platform and feel music bass as a result (she loves music).

2015 Teams.Project Description: Joystick/bluetooth mouse with sip and puff capabilities

2015 Teams.Project Description: Music page turner activated by head motion
